Olivier Assayas' film stars Asia Argento as a woman who had a relationship with Michael Madsen. Madsen is a business man who is hiding his identity in a village in the Italian countryside. Dounia – the woman – wants an explanation from Madsen. Assayas' has a way of keeping the audience engaged by not giving the complete story off the bat. The intensity comes from the viewer not knowing everything and wanting to know.

Reading through these comments, I see a remarkable socio-cultural clash theme emerging between the US and... the Dutch! The US expresses a sense of entitlement to sit where it pleases - "waiting my turn" -, and the Dutch continue to challenge this deeply ingrained U.S. travel ethic by insisting on demanding respect for their own values through confrontation.

But I have to ask the Dutch, do these confrontations actually solve anything

River Queen attempts to pack a complicated, sweeping, historical narrative into just under two hours. There are some breathtaking battle scenes and the Wanganui scenery is beautiful, well suited to Universal’s scope and scale. But the editing here is strange: attempting to tell the life of Douglas Munro in just over an hour and a half. After watching this movie, I couldn't help but notice the parallels between it and another film called America 3000. Both were very bad mid 1980's scifi movies that feature a girl who fantasizes about robots (like Wall-e) and ultimately winds up on some planet that she mistakenly believes to be Earth. Curious about this one? Michael Dudikoff stars as Joe Armstrong a martial artist who fights ninjas who are stealing weapons from the U.S Army, in this entertaining yet admittedly brainless comedic action film. This film is going to be criticized by some because it has very little action in it but I recommend it for what it is which is basically a TV series that was transferred to the big screen with a larger budget but also a much smaller script. I actually enjoyed this film because the comedy really worked
